As an adult I'm under 5 feet, as a growing kid I was *small* in every way possible. I always stretched height before my weight eventually followed so every growth spurt made me way too skinny for my height for a while. In junior high my PE teacher thought I was anorexic and was about to call my mom because she could see my ribcage lines through my tank top while stretching my back and my collar bones were very out there for the world to see as well. She had also seen me skip lunch/eat only bread/the fruit we often had for dessert a couple of times. I just have IBS, if it was flaring I didn't want to eat lunch because my stomach was hurting and I only wanted enough to not feel hungry. She finally agreed to not call my mom but she watched me like a hawk for weeks at lunch. Eventually she was sure that I did actually eat food and only was a bit picky with certain foods (which made my stomach hurt).

I've been to both sides.  From 140 lbs to 220 lbs. I'm 5 ft 7 btw and my bones tend to be dense. There are minuses and plusses to both sides. When I was skinny, while, yes, having the availability to wear cute clothes without shopping online because for your country, plus size = grandma clothing, there were some minuses. Please keep in mind I'm in Europe. Your butt hurts if you sit too long. But having a bigger butt means having difficulty finding clothes that fit well without showing everything. People constantly commented and complimented my skinniness, but that kind of creates a toxic environment for women based on body type. If you're pretty and skinny, you might be considered dumb or even derogatory things like bimbo, while if you're plus size, you're only that. Just fat. You may not even have the chance to show who you are before an assumption comes up that you live in your fridge. While you get positive treatment, plus sized women get bullied and treated like second-class humans. You get unwanted attention if you're skinny. It can get creepy at times. Have had guys chase me or just be absolute creeps. Everybody in your family or surroundings is super concerned about your bodily beauty and God forbid you gain weight. You won't hear the end of it. Back to the preferential treatment - you may not want it, but it happens, causing tension between your colleagues or friends. Some people hate you just for fitting the standard of beauty and size S or M clothing, which is a whole other toxic slew. The fashion industry and its sizes just gross on so many levels no.matter what size you wear, it gets smaller and smaller and you get called fatter and fatter even if you have stayed the same size, weight or body type for your entire life. Unless you get "fat". Then you make them look prettier just by being present. Thankfully, I have disconnected myself from toxic people like this. Not because I think too highly of myself. I think highly of my friends. Before they need me as an accessory to make them look prettier, they need to realize that they can be pretty in their own uniqueness without needing me. On the other hand, being plus sized has freed me. I used to struggle with body dysmorphia and still do, but rn I kind of give less effs. I still work out and try to eat healthy as much as I can, but. At least I found a person who loves me and appreciates my existence no matter what. We're currently planning a wedding.

I used to work at an ice cream shop when i was 17 and 18. I got SO. MANY. DAMN. COMMENTS. "Man, i wish i had your metabolism". "Oh, i could never be that skinny if i worked here." "How do you resist all the ice cream? I'd have an even bigger belly."   These were mostly from men... Wait. I think majority of them (if not all) we're from middle aged dudes (white mostly as well). Context: I was 6'1" and 150 at the time.   I did however get comments from my family all the time. Especially around 18 and 19.   Worst of all, I have debilitating medical issues. But cause im tall and thin everyone asks if i play basketball or volleyball. Then if i say no i get some degree of shamed for it! Like. First off, i don't have to tell you shit about my hobbies. Second, any reason is a 'good' reason to not play a sport or do something. Me being disabled does not make it "okay" to skip on sports. TALL PEOPLE DO NOT HAVE TO BE ATHLETIC. ESPECIALLY TALL GIRLS.   So much of my dysphoria comes from being tall and afab and everyone wanting tall girls to step on them and crush them. Assuming that every tall person is automatically strong. When we are actually more likely to have joint problems and chronic pain issues!   Bottom line. Just dont comment on people's weight or how much they eat. You have no idea what's going through their mind and your "funny" or "helpful" comments can really hurt someone.   (Fat shaming is bad. Period. I recognize the struggle of fat individuals, especially afab, in the healthcare field and how discriminatory it is towards y'all. It's bad and stupid and wrong. Yall deserve so much more. I was pretty built when I was 16, but one year on 4th of July I had an accident involving a 15ft rock face a lake and a rock that was very close to the Surface of the water that was not visible.  So basically I was at a family friends house and my motherâ€™s friend asked me and a few other family members if we would like to jump of a cliff into some water, and of course all of us being teenagers we said yes (This was also a grown woman whom we trusted to not kill us). She she drove us on her boat to the â€œjump areaâ€ and basically told me to go first which I did. I swam right over where I would go in not feeling anything or seeing anything, I then climbed up the side of the cliff face and jumped in pencil dive feet firstâ€¦ And hit a rock straight away from 15ft up, I then stood up and the water was right up to my waist. Everyone was very shocked that I was standing in such shallow water and so was I, I think the reason I was not in pain was adrenaline but we ended up stopping that straight away and quickly rushed me back to the lake house, where I waited for like 5 hours just sat in a chair. It turned out she went to the wrong place also so yeah. But my legs and ankles ended up swelling like two times their normal size and became extremely painful. To not ruin the fun for everyone else I had to wait there. We would end up getting home late and my parents told me they would take me to the hospital. The next day we got to the hospital and told the doctors what happened, they all looked very shocked and told me that I didnâ€™t look great or something. I had like 12 X-rays to check my legs, ankles, back, neck, and other stuff. By some miracle nothing was broken like nothing at all and the doctor said that I should be completely paralyzed or dead, somehow not even a bone was broken. I did however have two pretty bad sprains in both my ankles.  I would end up having braces. Then like two months later I would have to go back because I was having really bad knee problems and had to get braces for them. Then like a month later my back would go down hill. I would end up being in crutches for a whole year. Throughout that whole time more things going wrong, as well as my legs and feet turning dark purple constantly. And that would all suck. Through all of the not being able to move my legs and stuff I would lose a lot of weight in my legs and butt and it looked very un proportionate to the rest of my body. Basically what I am saying is I understand that thing about sitting on chairs and how it hurt loads from having no meat down their. THE PAIN IS SERIOUS ON MY RIBS
I have Crohn's. My weight fluctuates between 92 & 225 lbs. When I'm skinny I am not taken seriously because I'm too skinny to have opinions about weight & diet & lifestyle. When I am large I am misdiagnosed and treated poorly. When I'm skinny I get free upgrades on car rentals. When I'm large I get told my pain (Spondylo-Arthropathy)  is because of depression and inactivity not because I've had autoimmune issues since age 18. I almost died of blood clots because I was too fat for people to believe I was telling the truth. I feel you. Most people can't say that it stinks to be both too skinny and too fat. At too skinny it's always "You need to eat something!" Or "You're so skinny, how can you know what it is like to live life as a fat person?" I feel your pain. Why is so much of life and medical care based on an antiquated idea of weight? 23 years and I'm still confused  & frustrated.

But that is true, some years ago, ok maybe more than a few, (around middle school age) I had very unstable metabolism, I lost and gained weight like it was nonodies business, so I was constantly in both sides of the issue, going from being very chunky, to very Skinny, and very chunky, again and again for  a few years, and the issues are real, it's all true, people do say horrible things without a care, clothes don't fit, the floor hurts, but people hurt more, because they are constantly harassing anyone they can.  When I was skinny people made fun of it and told me to "eat meat", "eat a burger," "get on some calories" all those things (things I couldn't do because of health problems back then) and I had to constantly fix and repurpose clothes so they would fit well and not fall off, and the belts don't work, they fall off right along with clothesğŸ˜’  Finding the right sizes that actually fit was hell, (and store attendants don't always help, sometimes they can make things worse)  and lying anywhere that is even slightly hard hurts, (I love sleeping in the floor since it relaxes be but back then I couldn't do that because my bones hurt, it was my favorite thing and I couldn't do it, it was sorta sad,)  As for insulation, I don't know about that, I get freezing cold weather I'm chunky or not, I gotta wear layers upon layers of sweaters just so I don't catch a cold even of it's not that cold outside, (and I love the cold but I can't stand it, I get sick very fastğŸ¥²)    But yes, being skinny was nice, struggling with incomprehension, body image issues, and overall having people make fun of me was not.  And then when I gained back the weight I lost, the problems were much the same, I'll fitted clothes, mean comments.  At least now I know I can simply ignore everything and live like it's no big deal, if people say stuff just ignore it, if the floor is hard just get extra pillows, if I'm hungry I eat what I want and hope for the best! And if clothes don't fit... Just look the biggest size available and learn sewing/pinching hacksğŸ˜’ that'll save you a lot of trouble and money, and it'll look however you want it whenever you want it.

Lol
People please stop ruining your belts poking holes in them like noobs... These holes will make your belt weaker and if you need a another one because you gained or lost a little weight is gonna look baaaad... Here's a smarter way:  Step 1 (Measure): Put the belt around your waist and mark the position where you'd like the new hole to be by pressing the prong against the belt. Now measure the distance from the mark to the middle hole.  Step 2 (Disassemble): Unscrew the screw and take off the buckle, loop and all that things at that end, remember how you disassemble them, you'll need to put them together later.  Step 3 (Cut and punch): Now use the measure you took before to decide where  you will cut the belt from the side where the buckle was. Put the piece you just cut off on the belt lining up the  edges. Now use the old hole as stencil for the new one.  Step 4 (Reassemble): Put back together the loop, buckle and screw.  Et voilÃ !

HONESTLY, this is shit I struggle with all the time. I'm pretty skinny just naturally, but I have trouble with eating enough food so I'm like, MEGA SKINNY.  Sitting, especially on hard seats, hurts like hell. I'm also super tall so clothes are either too short and/or too big. I'll be damn lucky to find clothes that fit comfortably. Being skinny makes it feel awkward and weird to move around, hence the inability to dance. Personally, I haven't had any issues with getting too cold.  And this is a thing that people are super quick to shut down or get mad at you for because of body image issues. We have this idea of the "ideal" body, which is generally being thin, slim, skinny, etc. And maybe I take the fact that I am slim for granted, but because of that, the issues and annoyances start to shine through. And just because I'm skinny, that doesn't mean I don't have body image issues. I feel like I'm too skinny. I feel like I'm fragile and weak, and I wish I had a bit more fat or muscle on me.  Sorry for that full blown rant, this just really resonated with me ğŸ˜…  TL;DR  Being skinny also has it's downsides, and I can relate with that.ğŸ‘Œ

If you can't dance it means you have no rhythm. Just listen to the beat and you'll learn
If you buy a belt that is too long don't poke holes into it. Unless you have the right tool your new holes won't look nice.  The right way to fit a belt is to cut the end with the belt buckle. Before you cut put on the belt and pull it until it reaches the desidered tightness. At this point make a sign (on the inside) where the tongue would go as you would do if you were make a hole. Now measure the distance between your sign and the central hole (usually there are three holes).On the inside of the belt there should be a screw. Unscrew it and cut a length equal to your previous measurement. Using the piece of belt you just cut as a reference make a new hole (don't worry if the new hole isn't perfect because it won't be visible from the outside) and simply screw back the belt buckle on the belt.

I don't know the struggle for now but here's something about that: I am a trans women and just began HRT, and one of the drugs you take for hormone replacement therapy is spironolactone.   Spironolactone is an inhibitor of androgens and male sex hormones, i.e. testosterone. Once that's inhibited, it's steadily released as urine throughout your usage since it also effects water retention. But testosterone is also responsible for something beyond male stuff.  Testosterone helps manage muscle mass and, as you take spiro AND estradiol to become more femme, you start to lose weight through muscle degeneration or muscle atrophy. So I might not the struggle now, but check back in after two-four years and I'll be right there with ya lmao

I relate to all of these except the last one
I've always been overweight all my life (I still am), so I kinda know where you're coming from. The most relatable one was the comments people said because of my appearance. When I was in primary school, so many people would come up to me and tell me a variety of things, such as "Oh my God, you should lose some weight' and "I would be ashamed to have a child as fat as you" and "You should stop eating/go on a diet." All these comments left me hating my body for many years, which almost caused me to develop an eating disorder.  Another relatable thing would be the clothes never fitting. Instead of my clothes being too big, they've always been too small. It would be hard to find clothes that wouldn't hug me skin tight or enhance my fatness and make me look worse. Society in general just needs to do better with size diversity and acceptance.  Last thing: I have a friend who's really slim (she doesn't like the term skinny), and another friend who's the average/ideal weight. My slim friend has also faced the issues that you face. My average weight friend always gets compliments when she's alone, but when she's spotted with us, so many people make offensive remarks. Despite people always saying nice things to her, she ignored them because she knew they were saying those things since she didn't look like her other friends. She's a really good friend who's always been their for me and my slim friend, even if we're not the same weight has her.  Anyways, yeah. Sorry for it being so long, I just wanted to share my experience

All are fat people problems too lol. Chairs can pinch, get stuck, and we have more cushion to get sore. You fat and lay down, good luck getting up. It sucks. I havent been able to a push up since first grade. When we lay down, our fat spreads and flattens out. It doesnt stay close to our bones, so they get exposed. Chances are, there is no muscle to protect. Then weight can cause bones to pop out, because they arent meant to carry so much.  Insulation is just the opposite. 90 degrees and up is the same as saying hell. For clothes, either length/width dosent work. If not then how low/high the straddle is. I would rather add holes to belts than need to buy a new one. Society says we will die in our 50s. Cut back and eat healthier, workout, even though many do. Too heavy to get on this ride etc. As for dance moves, we got the jiggle, or chunkle shuffle. Fat and skinny are 2 sides of the same coin, it sucks either way.
